Award.AwardTitle: CRII: RI: Using Large-Scale Neuroanatomy Datasets to Quantify the Mesoscale Architecture of the Brain

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Methods for revealing the global connections of the brain typically start by tracing a small number of neurons at a time. It is through performing many experiments, in different brain areas, and across many brains, that information can be aggregated and consolidated to produce detailed maps of the brain's global networks and architecture. The aim of this project is to develop new computational approaches for modeling the connectivity of the mouse brain, in order to reveal principles of wiring and information routing. The project will leverage whole-brain imaging datasets from the Allen Institute for Brain Science that each provide a small piece of the puzzle but when combined, can yield a picture of whole-brain connectivity. The outcomes of this research will be new maps of the global connectivity of the mouse brain, and a framework for studying the impact of disease and aging on whole-brain networks.

This project will develop a novel framework for analyzing whole-brain connectomics datasets to model high-level (mesoscopic) principles of wiring and architecture. To do this, tools from matrix factorization will be used to decompose large datasets from many brains into a collection of learned neural pathways or "parts" that, when combined, describe large volumes of data as succinctly as possible. To address the size of the datasets, the use of subsampling-based approaches and randomized methods will be explored for massive-scale machine learning applications. Through intelligent and adaptive subsampling of the data, in combination with online methods for factorization, methods will be developed to process and learn from the entire Allen Institute Mouse Connectivity Atlas at less than 10-micron resolution. The outcomes of this project will be new tools for large-scale matrix factorization, models of the whole brain connectome, and discovery of wiring principles that could be useful in the development of next generation architectures for machine intelligence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The past decade has experienced rapid growth in new imaging methods to capture the brain's structure and organization across many spatial scales and volumes. Moving from the large volumes of data produced by these approaches to generate models of brain structure, remains a major challenge.

The aim of this project was to develop new ways to model and compare the structure and organization of many brains using machine learning (ML) approaches. As a result of this project and NSF sponsored funding, we made a number of important contributions to both neuroscience and ML which we highlight below. 

(1) Representation learning from high-resolution neuroimaging datasets: To automate the process of brain region discovery, we developed a deep learning system that could go directly from small views in an image to predict different regions of interest. We show that by training the system to find differences across macroscale regions, the representations formed in the network could be dissected and factorized to reveal even finer scale differences in the composition of cells and axons in brain tissue. This effort lead to three papers (see Balwani, et al., Asilomar, 2019), as well as an open-access dataset and resource (bossdb.org/project/prasad2020; Prasad, et al., Sci Data, 2020) that provides synchrotron X-ray microtomography image volumes and annotations of different brain regions therein.

(2) Generative modeling framework for neuroanatomy image datasets to dissect different sources of population-level variability: To better understand how individual variability in brain structure could be learned and interpreted, we designed an approach to both learn a generative model for brain images and then understand which brain regions co-vary across many individuals. We applied our machine learning interpretability approach to the Allen Institute's Mouse Connectivity Atlas to reveal unique factors in our model that control variance in specific brain regions-of-interest. This effort led to one conference paper (see Liu, et al., MICCAI, 2020). Moving forward, we hope to build in better ways to guide the network to disentangle the different factors of variance directly, rather than trying to interpret the factors post-hoc.

(3) Novel optimal transport methods for distribution alignment and their applications in neuroscience: A major challenge that we face when trying to compare data from two different brains or two connectomes is the issue of alignment. When dealing with image alignment in 2 or 3-dimensions, this can be relatively easy. However, when trying to align datasets of higher dimensions, this problem becomes much more challenging. During this project, we made a number of important advances in the development of general tools for distribution alignment. Specifically, we developed a new technique for cluster-based alignment that uses the Wasserstein distance to smooth the problem and improve alignment significantly (see Lee et al., NeurIPS, 2019). We applied this method to align neural activities across two individuals, using a common set of movements to serve as an intermediate target. In follow up work (see Lin, et al., 2021), we developed a strategy to simultaneously learn structure in data along with alignment to rule out many unfavorable solutions.

All of these contributions will have major impacts on their respective disciplines which span neuroanatomy, connectomics, machine learning, and mathematics. The first two sets of contributions will impact the neuroanatomy communities by providing new ways to leverage state-of-the-art technologies in deep learning for modeling brain organization and population-level variability. The third set of contributions has already had impacts in ML and inspired other extensions of this idea to more complex hierarchical data structures.
